items.title: Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi hopes for big win in snap elections
items.standfirst: Polls opened Sunday in parliamentary elections that Japan's popular Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi hopes will give her struggling party a big enough win to push through an ambitious conservative political agenda. Story by Nicholas Rushworth.
items.content: Polls opened Sunday in parliamentary elections that Japan's popular Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi hopes will give her struggling party a big enough win to push through an ambitious conservative political agenda. Story by Nicholas Rushworth.

items.title: Japanese people brave snow to vote in snap election
items.standfirst: Japanese people are braving the snow to vote in a snap election called by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, whose coalition is predicted to clinch a decisive win. Takaichi called the country's first mid-winter poll in 36 years to seek a public mandate soon after winning her party's leadership race…
items.content: Japanese people are braving the snow to vote in a snap election called by Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, whose coalition is predicted to clinch a decisive win. Takaichi called the country's first mid-winter poll in 36 years to seek a public mandate soon after winning her party's leadership race…

items.title: Japan’s Takaichi hopes for strong majority in snow-hit snap elections
items.standfirst: Japan's right-wing Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi is eyeing a possible two-thirds majority in the country's lower house on Sunday as the country fights its way through heavy snowfall to vote in snap legislative elections. Takaichi, who comes from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's ultra-conservative fringe, has promised to suspend a sales tax on food to tackle rising prices.
items.content: Japan's right-wing Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi is eyeing a possible two-thirds majority in the country's lower house on Sunday as the country fights its way through heavy snowfall to vote in snap legislative elections. Takaichi, who comes from the ruling Liberal Democratic Party's ultra-conservative fringe, has promised to suspend a sales tax on food to tackle rising prices.

items.title: Japan's ultraconservative PM Sanae Takaichi set for a big election victory

clusters.neutral_headline: Washington Post CEO resigns after sweeping layoffs
bullet_summary: The chief executive of the Washington Post is stepping down, the newspaper has announced, days after overseeing mass lay-offs
In a message to staff, William Lewis said it was the right time to leave and that "difficult decisions" had been made to ensure the paper's future

items.title: Washington Post CEO resigns after sweeping job cuts
items.standfirst: The Washington Post said Saturday its CEO and publisher Will Lewis was leaving effective immediately, just days after the storied newspaper owned by billionaire Amazon founder Jeff Bezos made drastic job cuts that angered readers. Story by Simon Moritz.
items.content: The Washington Post said Saturday its CEO and publisher Will Lewis was leaving effective immediately, just days after the storied newspaper owned by billionaire Amazon founder Jeff Bezos made drastic job cuts that angered readers. Story by Simon Moritz.

items.title: Hilary Knight shows the world why she's one of the greatest at 2026 Olympics
items.standfirst: Ice hockey forward Hilary Knight showed the world why she's one of the greatest players ever. With her 14th goal, the captain of Team USA moved into a tie for the most goals scored by a U.S. Women's hockey player at the Winter Olympics. Andres Gutierrez reports on her career and her last Olympic run.
items.content: Ice hockey forward Hilary Knight showed the world why she's one of the greatest players ever. With her 14th goal, the captain of Team USA moved into a tie for the most goals scored by a U.S. Women's hockey player at the Winter Olympics. Andres Gutierrez reports on her career and her last Olympic run.

items.content: "We received your message," the US news anchor says in the latest video plea for the return of her mother Nancy Guthrie, 84, who is believed to be abducted.

items.content: Savannah Guthrie released a new video​ on Saturday, saying her family is willing to pay for the safe return of their mother.

items.title: Savannah Guthrie makes another video plea: "This is very valuable to us and we will pay"
items.standfirst: Saturday marks one week since Nancy Guthrie, mother of "Today" show host Savannah Guthrie, was last seen by her family. Andres Gutierrez has the latest on the investigation.
items.content: Saturday marks one week since Nancy Guthrie, mother of "Today" show host Savannah Guthrie, was last seen by her family. Andres Gutierrez has the latest on the investigation.

items.title: 'We will pay,' Savannah Guthrie says in desperate video plea to potential kidnappers of her mother
items.standfirst: Today show host tells potential kidnappers of mother Nancy that family is prepared to pay for safe returnSavannah Guthrie told the potential kidnappers of her mother, Nancy Guthrie, on Saturday that the family is prepared to pay for her safe return, as the frantic search for the 84-year-old entered a seventh day.“We received your message, and we understand. We beg you now to return our mother to us so that we can celebrate with her,” she said in a video posted on social media, flanked by her siblings. “This is the only way we will have peace. This is very valuable to us, and we will pay.” Continue reading...
items.content: Today show host tells potential kidnappers of mother Nancy that family is prepared to pay for safe returnSavannah Guthrie told the potential kidnappers of her mother, Nancy Guthrie, on Saturday that the family is prepared to pay for her safe return, as the frantic search for the 84-year-old entered a seventh day.“We received your message, and we understand. We beg you now to return our mother to us so that we can celebrate with her,” she said in a video posted on social media, flanked by her siblings. “This is the only way we will have peace. This is very valuable to us, and we will pay.” Continue reading...

items.title: One week since Nancy Guthrie was last seen, here's what we know
items.standfirst: Nancy Guthrie was last seen a week ago. In the days since, investigators have launched a frantic search to return the 84-year-old home.
items.content: Nancy Guthrie was last seen a week ago. In the days since, investigators have launched a frantic search to return the 84-year-old home.(Image credit: AP)

clusters.title: Polls wrap up in Thailand's election, incumbent PM seeks new term
clusters.neutral_headline: Polls close in Thailand as reformists, conservatives vie for power
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, NPR News, Al Jazeera

items.title: Polls wrap up in Thailand's election, incumbent PM seeks new term
items.standfirst: Vote counting was underway in Thailand's early general election on Sunday, seen as a three-way race among competing visions of progressive, populist and old-fashioned patronage politics. Coalition negotiations are expected to follow soon after, with no party forecast to secure an overall majority. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondant in Bangkok, Tommy Walker.
items.content: Vote counting was underway in Thailand's early general election on Sunday, seen as a three-way race among competing visions of progressive, populist and old-fashioned patronage politics. Coalition negotiations are expected to follow soon after, with no party forecast to secure an overall majority. Details by FRANCE 24 correspondant in Bangkok, Tommy Walker.

items.title: Thailand counts votes in early election with 3 main parties vying for power

items.content: Vote counting was underway in Thailand's early general election on Sunday, seen as a three-way race among competing visions of progressive, populist and old-fashioned patronage politics.(Image credit: Wason Wanichakorn)

items.title: Thailand votes in three-way race under military scrutiny
items.standfirst: Voters in Thailand came out in numbers ⁠on Sunday for a general election defined by a three-way battle between conservative, progressive and populist camps, with no single party expected to secure a clear majority and prolonging the spectre of political instability. Report by Justin McCurry, Constantin Simon, Theo Collet, Adrien Quilici and Goy Supassorn.
items.content: Voters in Thailand came out in numbers ⁠on Sunday for a general election defined by a three-way battle between conservative, progressive and populist camps, with no single party expected to secure a clear majority and prolonging the spectre of political instability. Report by Justin McCurry, Constantin Simon, Theo Collet, Adrien Quilici and Goy Supassorn.

items.title: 'It's about getting the economy back up and running': Thailand votes in general election
items.standfirst: As Thailand votes in a three-way race pitting progressives against populists and conservatives, FRANCE 24 correspondent Tommy Walker explains how the Southeast Asian nation's sluggish economic growth is weighing heavily on the minds of voters craving better jobs and better pay.
items.content: As Thailand votes in a three-way race pitting progressives against populists and conservatives, FRANCE 24 correspondent Tommy Walker explains how the Southeast Asian nation's sluggish economic growth is weighing heavily on the minds of voters craving better jobs and better pay.

items.title: Polls close in Thailand as reformists, conservatives vie for power
items.standfirst: No single party is expected to secure a clear majority in Sunday's vote, raising the spectre of political instability.
items.content: No single party is expected to secure a clear majority in Sunday's vote, raising the spectre of political instability.

items.title: Thailand votes in three-way race as country struggles with sluggish economic growth
items.standfirst: Thai voters once again cast their ballots Sunday in a general election pitting the military-backed ruling conservatives against the poll-leading progressive People's Party and Thaksin Shinawatra's populist Pheu Thai party. No party is predicted to emerge from Sunday's elections with an outright parliamentary majority.
items.content: Thai voters once again cast their ballots Sunday in a general election pitting the military-backed ruling conservatives against the poll-leading progressive People's Party and Thaksin Shinawatra's populist Pheu Thai party. No party is predicted to emerge from Sunday's elections with an outright parliamentary majority.

items.title: Former French minister resigns over Epstein-linked tax fraud probe
items.standfirst: France’s former Culture Minister Jack Lang has resigned as head of a Paris cultural center over alleged past financial links to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein that prompted a tax investigation. Story by Nicholas Rushworth.
items.content: France’s former Culture Minister Jack Lang has resigned as head of a Paris cultural center over alleged past financial links to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein that prompted a tax investigation. Story by Nicholas Rushworth.

items.title: Veteran French politician quits as head of prestigious institute after Epstein links revealed
items.standfirst: Former culture minister Jack Lang resigns from Arab World Institute in Paris and is also subject of tax investigationJack Lang, a former French culture minister, has resigned as head of Paris’s prestigious Arab World Institute after revelations of his past contacts with the disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and the launch of a financial investigation by French prosecutors.Lang, 86, resigned on Saturday night before he was due to attend an urgent meeting called by the French foreign ministry to discuss his links to Epstein. Continue reading...
items.content: Former culture minister Jack Lang resigns from Arab World Institute in Paris and is also subject of tax investigationJack Lang, a former French culture minister, has resigned as head of Paris’s prestigious Arab World Institute after revelations of his past contacts with the disgraced financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and the launch of a financial investigation by French prosecutors.Lang, 86, resigned on Saturday night before he was due to attend an urgent meeting called by the French foreign ministry to discuss his links to Epstein. Continue reading...

items.title: France investigates ex-minister Jack Lang over Epstein links
items.standfirst: The socialist grandee quits his role at a prestigious institute as he is investigated for the "laundering of tax-fraud proceeds".
items.content: The socialist grandee quits his role at a prestigious institute as he is investigated for the "laundering of tax-fraud proceeds".

items.title: France’s former minister Jack Lang ‘offers’ to resign from Arab World Institute over Epstein links
items.standfirst: Jack Lang, France’s former culture minister, on Saturday “offered” to resign as head of the prestigious Arab World Institute in Paris after he and his daughter Caroline were mentioned in the latest batch of documents related to the late financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The day before, France’s financial crimes prosecutors announced they had opened a probe into the Lang family’s ties with Epstein. Lang is also due to appear before Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot after being summoned.
items.content: Jack Lang, France’s former culture minister, on Saturday “offered” to resign as head of the prestigious Arab World Institute in Paris after he and his daughter Caroline were mentioned in the latest batch of documents related to the late financier and sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The day before, France’s financial crimes prosecutors announced they had opened a probe into the Lang family’s ties with Epstein. Lang is also due to appear before Foreign Minister Jean-Noël Barrot after being summoned.

clusters.title: Bad Bunny set to electrify Super Bowl for Patriots-Seahawks showdown as politics swirl
clusters.neutral_headline: What the Super Bowl means to American fans
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, BBC World

items.title: Bad Bunny set to electrify Super Bowl for Patriots-Seahawks showdown as politics swirl
items.standfirst: American football fans are gearing up for the annual title decider, the Super Bowl. The Seattle Seahawks are up against the New England Patriots. But as always, the half time performance is arguably the bigger story. Bad Bunny, the Grammy winning Puerto Rican superstar, is expected to sing his set entirely in Spanish. He's been a vocal critic of the government's immigration crackdown... and everyone is wondering just how political it could get. Our correspondent Loic Pialat met some fans.
items.content: American football fans are gearing up for the annual title decider, the Super Bowl. The Seattle Seahawks are up against the New England Patriots. But as always, the half time performance is arguably the bigger story. Bad Bunny, the Grammy winning Puerto Rican superstar, is expected to sing his set entirely in Spanish. He's been a vocal critic of the government's immigration crackdown... and everyone is wondering just how political it could get. Our correspondent Loic Pialat met some fans.

items.title: Super Bowl set for Patriots-Seahawks showdown as Bad Bunny half-time show sparks controversy
items.standfirst: As the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks prepare to go toe-to-toe at the Super Bowl in Santa Clara, California on Sunday, many people will be tuning in to watch a historic – and potentially political – half-time performance by Puerto Rican artist Bad Bunny.
items.content: As the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks prepare to go toe-to-toe at the Super Bowl in Santa Clara, California on Sunday, many people will be tuning in to watch a historic – and potentially political – half-time performance by Puerto Rican artist Bad Bunny.

items.title: What the Super Bowl means to American fans
items.standfirst: NFL fans have flocked to California for Super Bowl LX, where the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks will face off at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara.
items.content: NFL fans have flocked to California for Super Bowl LX, where the New England Patriots and Seattle Seahawks will face off at Levi's Stadium in Santa Clara.

clusters.title: France and Canada open consulates in Greenland after US threats
clusters.neutral_headline: Canada and France open Greenland consulates in show of Denmark support
bullet_summary: Reported by France24, Guardian World

items.title: France and Canada open consulates in Greenland after US threats
items.standfirst: Canada and France opened diplomatic consulates on Friday in the capital of Greenland, showing support for NATO ally Denmark and the Arctic island in the wake of US efforts to secure control of the semiautonomous Danish territory. Story by Jennie Shin.
items.content: Canada and France opened diplomatic consulates on Friday in the capital of Greenland, showing support for NATO ally Denmark and the Arctic island in the wake of US efforts to secure control of the semiautonomous Danish territory. Story by Jennie Shin.

items.title: Canada and France open Greenland consulates in show of Denmark support
items.standfirst: Founding of diplomatic outposts in Nuuk comes after US made efforts to secure control of Arctic islandOpposition to US has hardened in western Europe after Greenland threat, poll findsCanada and France are to open diplomatic consulates in the capital of Greenland on Friday, showing support for their Nato ally Denmark and the Arctic island after US efforts to secure control of the semi-autonomous Danish territory.Canada’s foreign minister, Anita Anand, was travelling to Nuuk to inaugurate the consulate, which officials say also could help boost cooperation on issues such as the climate crisis and Inuit rights. She was joined by Canada’s Indigenous governor general, Mary Simon. Continue reading...
items.content: Founding of diplomatic outposts in Nuuk comes after US made efforts to secure control of Arctic islandOpposition to US has hardened in western Europe after Greenland threat, poll findsCanada and France are to open diplomatic consulates in the capital of Greenland on Friday, showing support for their Nato ally Denmark and the Arctic island after US efforts to secure control of the semi-autonomous Danish territory.Canada’s foreign minister, Anita Anand, was travelling to Nuuk to inaugurate the consulate, which officials say also could help boost cooperation on issues such as the climate crisis and Inuit rights. She was joined by Canada’s Indigenous governor general, Mary Simon. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Centre-left candidate expected to see off far right as Portugal votes in presidential runoff
clusters.neutral_headline: Centre-left candidate expected to see off far right as...

items.title: Centre-left candidate expected to see off far right as Portugal votes in presidential runoff
items.standfirst: António José Seguro tipped to beat populist André Ventura with support of mainstream politicians on left and rightThe centre-left Socialist candidate, António José Seguro, is heavily favoured to defeat the far-right populist André Ventura in Portugal’s runoff presidential election, in a vote that will test the depth of support for Ventura’s brash style of politics.Recent opinion polls suggest Seguro will collect twice as many votes as Ventura in the head to head on Sunday between the two top candidates in last month’s first round of voting, when none of the 11 runners captured the more than 50% of the vote required for victory. Continue reading...
items.content: António José Seguro tipped to beat populist André Ventura with support of mainstream politicians on left and rightThe centre-left Socialist candidate, António José Seguro, is heavily favoured to defeat the far-right populist André Ventura in Portugal’s runoff presidential election, in a vote that will test the depth of support for Ventura’s brash style of politics.Recent opinion polls suggest Seguro will collect twice as many votes as Ventura in the head to head on Sunday between the two top candidates in last month’s first round of voting, when none of the 11 runners captured the more than 50% of the vote required for victory. Continue reading...

items.title: Portugal chooses between centre-left Socialist and far-right firebrand in presidential runoff
items.standfirst: Centre-left Socialist candidate Antonio Jose Seguro is expected to win the second round of Portugal's presidential election Sunday after far-right populist Andre Ventura failed to unite the country's right wing behind his candidacy following the first round of voting last month.
items.content: Centre-left Socialist candidate Antonio Jose Seguro is expected to win the second round of Portugal's presidential election Sunday after far-right populist Andre Ventura failed to unite the country's right wing behind his candidacy following the first round of voting last month.

items.title: Live: Military pressure 'does not scare' Iran, FM says after US envoys visit aircraft carrier
items.standfirst: Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi declared Sunday that his country was not intimidated by the US naval deployment in the Gulf, two days after talks with Washington's envoy. US President Donald Trump's lead Iran negotiators Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner on Saturday visited the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier in the Arabian Sea. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.
items.content: Iran's Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi declared Sunday that his country was not intimidated by the US naval deployment in the Gulf, two days after talks with Washington's envoy. US President Donald Trump's lead Iran negotiators Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner on Saturday visited the USS Abraham Lincoln aircraft carrier in the Arabian Sea. Follow our liveblog for all the latest developments.

clusters.title: ‘We need to accept the cost’: future of British Steel unclear as bills for government build up
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘We need to accept the cost’: future of British Steel unclear...
bullet_summary: British Steel was losing £700,000 a day last year when its Chinese owner announced plans to shut the steelworks at Scunthorpe
Reported by Reuters Top News, Guardian World

items.title: ‘We need to accept the cost’: future of British Steel unclear as bills for government build up
items.standfirst: Propping up operations at Scunthorpe site, still legally owned by Jingye, now costs over £1.2m a day – so what are the options? British Steel was losing £700,000 a day last year when its Chinese owner announced plans to shut the steelworks at Scunthorpe. After Jingye rejected support to buy raw…
items.content: Propping up operations at Scunthorpe site, still legally owned by Jingye, now costs over £1.2m a day – so what are the options? British Steel was losing £700,000 a day last year when its Chinese owner announced plans to shut the steelworks at Scunthorpe. After Jingye rejected support to buy raw…

items.title: ‘We need to accept the cost’: future of British Steel unclear as bills for government build up
items.standfirst: Propping up operations at Scunthorpe site, still legally owned by Jingye, now costs over £1.2m a day – so what are the options?British Steel was losing £700,000 a day last year when its Chinese owner announced plans to shut the steelworks at Scunthorpe. After Jingye rejected support to buy raw materials, the UK government stepped in with emergency legislation to take control of the plant.But that was not the end of the crisis. The cost to the government of propping up British Steel is now more than £1.2m a day. Yet the £359m bill, the latest disclosed to parliament last month, may only be the start. Continue reading...
items.content: Propping up operations at Scunthorpe site, still legally owned by Jingye, now costs over £1.2m a day – so what are the options?British Steel was losing £700,000 a day last year when its Chinese owner announced plans to shut the steelworks at Scunthorpe. After Jingye rejected support to buy raw materials, the UK government stepped in with emergency legislation to take control of the plant.But that was not the end of the crisis. The cost to the government of propping up British Steel is now more than £1.2m a day. Yet the £359m bill, the latest disclosed to parliament last month, may only be the start. Continue reading...

items.standfirst: Jeff Bezos’s axing of more than 300 jobs at the storied newspaper has renewed fears about the resilience of America’s democracy to withstand Trump’s attacks The email landed in Lizzie Johnson’s in-tray in Ukraine just before 4pm local time. It came at a tough time for the reporter: Russia had been…

items.title: As goes the Washington Post: US democracy takes another hit under Trump
items.standfirst: Jeff Bezos’s axing of more than 300 jobs at the storied newspaper has renewed fears about the resilience of America’s democracy to withstand Trump’s attacksThe email landed in Lizzie Johnson’s in-tray in Ukraine just before 4pm local time. It came at a tough time for the reporter: Russia had been repeatedly striking the country’s power grid, and just days before she had been forced to work out of her car without heat, power or running water, writing in pencil because pen ink freezes too readily.“Difficult news,” was the subject line. The body text said: “Your position is eliminated as part of today’s organizational changes,” explaining that it was necessary to get rid of her to meet the “evolving needs of our business”. Continue reading...
items.content: Jeff Bezos’s axing of more than 300 jobs at the storied newspaper has renewed fears about the resilience of America’s democracy to withstand Trump’s attacksThe email landed in Lizzie Johnson’s in-tray in Ukraine just before 4pm local time. It came at a tough time for the reporter: Russia had been repeatedly striking the country’s power grid, and just days before she had been forced to work out of her car without heat, power or running water, writing in pencil because pen ink freezes too readily.“Difficult news,” was the subject line. The body text said: “Your position is eliminated as part of today’s organizational changes,” explaining that it was necessary to get rid of her to meet the “evolving needs of our business”. Continue reading...

items.content: Italian police have fired tear gas and water cannon at protesters who threw firecrackers, smoke bombs and bottles at them near a Winter Olympics venue.

items.standfirst: Almost 1,000 Google employees have signed an open letter demanding that the company cut ties with the US Department of Homeland Security due to the Donald Trump administration. The petition cites Google contracts with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection…
items.content: Almost 1,000 Google employees have signed an open letter demanding that the company cut ties with the US Department of Homeland Security due to the Donald Trump administration. The petition cites Google contracts with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and Customs and Border Protection…

items.title: Google Employees Call on Company to End ICE, CBP Contracts
items.standfirst: More than 900 employees at Alphabet Inc.’s Google have signed a petition demanding that the company sever ties with the US Department of Homeland Security in the wake of the Trump administration’s mass deportation efforts.
items.content: More than 900 employees at Alphabet Inc.’s Google have signed a petition demanding that the company sever ties with the US Department of Homeland Security in the wake of the Trump administration’s mass deportation efforts.

clusters.title: Trump says he "didn't see" image depicting Obamas as apes in social media post
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump says he "didn't see" image depicting Obamas as apes in social media post
bullet_summary: Reported by CBS News, BBC World

items.title: Trump says he "didn't see" image depicting Obamas as apes in social media post
items.standfirst: President Trump late Friday addressed a video posted to his social media account that included a racist depiction of Barack and Michelle Obama as apes, telling reporters he didn't see the part that showed the former president and first lady.
items.content: President Trump late Friday addressed a video posted to his social media account that included a racist depiction of Barack and Michelle Obama as apes, telling reporters he didn't see the part that showed the former president and first lady.

items.title: Trump says he 'didn't see' part of video with racist clip depicting Obamas as apes
items.standfirst: The US president says he "didn't make a mistake", adding he had only seen the beginning of the video before it was posted.
items.content: The US president says he "didn't make a mistake", adding he had only seen the beginning of the video before it was posted.

Brad Arnold, the founder and lead singer of the 3 Doors Down has died following "his courageous battle with cancer," the rock band announced Saturday on social media

clusters.title: Haiti’s transitional council hands power to US-backed prime minister
clusters.neutral_headline: Haiti’s transitional council hands power to US-backed prime minister
bullet_summary: Reported by Al Jazeera, France24

items.title: Haiti’s transitional council hands power to US-backed prime minister
items.standfirst: Move comes after council tried to oust PM Fils-Aime and the US recently deployed warship to waters near Haiti’s capital.
items.content: Move comes after council tried to oust PM Fils-Aime and the US recently deployed warship to waters near Haiti’s capital.

items.title: Haiti’s transitional council transfers power to US-backed prime minister Fils-Aimé
items.standfirst: Haiti’s presidential transitional council on Saturday handed over power to US-backed Prime Minister Alix Didier Fils-Aimé as the country prepares for its first general elections in a decade. The council was created two years ago, but has been unable to quell the gang violence plaguing the Caribbean nation.
items.content: Haiti’s presidential transitional council on Saturday handed over power to US-backed Prime Minister Alix Didier Fils-Aimé as the country prepares for its first general elections in a decade. The council was created two years ago, but has been unable to quell the gang violence plaguing the Caribbean nation.

clusters.title: Trump pushes for peace in Ukraine ‘by June’, Zelensky says
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelenskyy says US has set June deadline for Ukraine-Russia peace deal
bullet_summary: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday said Washington has proposed that Russian and Ukrainian negotiators meet in the United States next week to discuss a possible peace deal
“They say they want to do everything by June,” Zelensky said of the US mediators
Zelenskyy said the Trump administration “will probably put pressure” on Ukraine and Russia to end the war by the beginning of the summer
“They say they want to get everything done by June,” he said

items.title: Trump pushes for peace in Ukraine ‘by June’, Zelensky says
items.standfirst: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday said Washington has proposed that Russian and Ukrainian negotiators meet in the United States next week to discuss a possible peace deal. “They say they want to do everything by June,” Zelensky said of the US mediators.
items.content: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday said Washington has proposed that Russian and Ukrainian negotiators meet in the United States next week to discuss a possible peace deal. “They say they want to do everything by June,” Zelensky said of the US mediators.

items.title: Zelenskyy says US has set June deadline for Ukraine-Russia peace deal
items.standfirst: Ukrainian president says Trump administration has proposed to host next round of trilateral talks in USVolodymyr Zelenskyy has said the US has given Ukraine and Russia yet another deadline to reach a peace settlement, and is now proposing the war should end by June. The Ukrainian president also told reporters that both sides had been invited to further talks next week.Zelenskyy said the Trump administration “will probably put pressure” on Ukraine and Russia to end the war by the beginning of the summer. “They say they want to get everything done by June,” he said. “They will do everything to end the war and they want a clear schedule of all events.” Continue reading...
items.content: Ukrainian president says Trump administration has proposed to host next round of trilateral talks in USVolodymyr Zelenskyy has said the US has given Ukraine and Russia yet another deadline to reach a peace settlement, and is now proposing the war should end by June. The Ukrainian president also told reporters that both sides had been invited to further talks next week.Zelenskyy said the Trump administration “will probably put pressure” on Ukraine and Russia to end the war by the beginning of the summer. “They say they want to get everything done by June,” he said. “They will do everything to end the war and they want a clear schedule of all events.” Continue reading...

clusters.title: RSF drone attack kills 24 people fleeing fighting in central Sudan, says doctors group
clusters.neutral_headline: Sudan drone attack kills 24 people, including eight children
bullet_summary: The vehicle was transporting displaced people who fled fighting in the Dubeiker area, the group said in a statement
Reported by Guardian World, Sky News World

items.title: RSF drone attack kills 24 people fleeing fighting in central Sudan, says doctors group
items.standfirst: Eight children including two infants among dead in vehicle carrying displaced people, says Sudan Doctors NetworkA drone attack by a paramilitary group has hit a vehicle carrying displaced families in central Sudan, killing at least 24 people, including eight children, a doctors’ group said on Saturday.The attack by the Rapid Support Forces took place close to the city of Er Rahad in North Kordofan province, according to the Sudan Doctors Network, which tracks the country’s war. The vehicle was transporting displaced people who fled fighting in the Dubeiker area, the group said in a statement. Among the dead children were two infants. Continue reading...
items.content: Eight children including two infants among dead in vehicle carrying displaced people, says Sudan Doctors NetworkA drone attack by a paramilitary group has hit a vehicle carrying displaced families in central Sudan, killing at least 24 people, including eight children, a doctors’ group said on Saturday.The attack by the Rapid Support Forces took place close to the city of Er Rahad in North Kordofan province, according to the Sudan Doctors Network, which tracks the country’s war. The vehicle was transporting displaced people who fled fighting in the Dubeiker area, the group said in a statement. Among the dead children were two infants. Continue reading...

items.title: Sudan drone attack kills 24 people, including eight children
items.standfirst: A drone attack in Sudan has killed 24 people, including eight children, according to a doctors' group.
items.content: A drone attack in Sudan has killed 24 people, including eight children, according to a doctors' group.
